snippet.textDisplay: I recall going to the doctor as I had sharp stomach pain bothering me for a few days. I would eat but feel like I never ate or would not have much of an appetite then as the stomach pain got worse, that's when I began to vomit. The stomach pain began to become excruciating. I have Sickle Cell Disease too but this was nothing like a sickle crises I have had before. However, as I am laying in the bed at emergency in tears from the excruciating pain, the nurse literally says "Oh honey it's not that bad, stop it" I said "excuse me..." My mom was in the room with me and I remember her being furious and having some words with that nurse and asked for the doctor right away. I am normally a good advocate for myself, I have grown to be, but I was so grateful to have my mom there with me to help be my voice because in that moment I don't think I would have had the strength with the pain I was in. I had to have a colonoscopy, I was only 19 or 20 at the time. It was informed at the time that I had gastritis and a form of colitis was mentioned as well. But that just goes to show to listen to your body cause if it was up to the nurse, my pain was not that bad...😒 I remember thinking how could someone say that when they are not experiencing what I am experiencing, especially with her being a nurse. The nurse demeanor was beyond rude and sarcastic, I couldn't believe it. Unfortunately, this is not the only story I have when people in the hospital has decided to ignore my pain or concerns I have addressed to them. But I recently have heard about telling them to put information in your chart for what they may have refused to do from what you asked of them. Thank you for throwing that tip out there for people to be aware of💙

snippet.textDisplay:
Scary.... you go for professional help and those nurses and doctors are not equal in healthcare?

They pledge on what? Money and statues and not the importance to save lives?

ER is a hectic place... triage nurse is the 1st gate to treatment (knowing how urgent is the health issue)

Im thankful for the doctors and nurses i've come across with. Each didn't care of my statues or ethnicity. They care that i was safe before leaving.

My case: I went through a miscarriage. Every step of the way, all i got was empathy and professionalism.

HOSPITALS:
Mackenzie Health - i found out
Humber Hospital - i went for further check up
North York General Hospital - i had my D&C

7 months later, thank God i was again pregnant. Now, i am 37 weeks preggy. I have gestational diabetes. Since it is my last month... i am being checked by three institions:
OBgyn
Diabetic clinic
Neonatal Stress Test

All lab works / ultrasound and checkup dates are free.... Thanks so much to OHIP

snippet.textDisplay: Your answer to bad healthcare is the ACA? Yeah so that more people will flood hospitals with tummy aches. The fact remains that hospitals have to prioritize who and what they think to be the biggest need. What you should be doing is advocating for the extinction of Insurance companies all together. They monopolize healthcare and don't allow patients to negotiate pricing. Furthermore they hide all the fees until after treatment so you will have no choice but to be stuck with bills following the treatment. We used to be able to pay for the best healthcare in the world via cash. it was far and away the best in the world, and the cheapest too. Now it is starting to falter, but more so wayyy too expensive. The answer isn't to kill it via government oversight. Governments can't run a damn post office, they won't be able to run hospitals. Nor are they going to negotiate better pricing for you via insurance. There is a reason people still come to the US when they are in serious need of major surgeries. Canadians especially. If you want to live a life where you wait 8 weeks just for a broken hip, so be it. I don't. Mother especially should be able to go into hospitals and receive the best treatment immediately, and no government program or insurance is going to make that happen.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm glad they spoke about this topic. I am a RN and black women and know these stats. When I was pregnant with my twins I had extreme anxiety about my pregnancy, giving birth and recovery. I vetted my OBGYN thoroghly and when she retired in the middle of my pregnancy my heart was broken. I was given another doctor in the practice and when I felt like she wasn't a good fit I requestes another. I encourage women to read about pregnancy(from legit sources) and educate yourself. I was lucky enough to have a both a specialist and OBGYN doctor that took me seriously. If your doctor doesn't stand up for you, find ANOTHER or maybe even a nurse midwife. My doctor's where the ones ensuring I had what I needed while at the hospital. It is important to have a healthcare provider you have a report with. If someone else delivers you and you don't feel like you are being heard ask for your doctor or someone for there practice. Nurse isn't hearing you ask for the charge nurse or a different nurse. Most hospitals have patient advocates request one if you are having issues.

snippet.textDisplay: As a nurse in the emergency department there is so much that goes into account when you have someone present to the ER with chest pain. You evaluate this person and you are trained to recognize signs and symptoms of an urgent vs emergent scenario. You look at risk factors and a host of other vital signs. I don’t know how this young woman was evaluated or triaged, but if at the initial evaluation she was deemed urgent instead of emergent. Given her age (not her race) her risk factors were lower for a cardiac event. She most likely got and EKG and at that point in time was not having a cardiac event, therefore she was essentially placed below other emergencies such as CPR, or respiratory failures, etc. Unfortunately there are not always enough resources to care for everyone at certain points in time. Unfortunately this patient deteriorated while waiting. What people don’t see in emergency rooms is not just a full waiting room of patients, but that ambulances are brining in patients as well some that will die without immediate intervention. You cannot predict certain emergent situations or even how quickly someone will deteriorate while waiting.

snippet.textDisplay:
I see in the comments some people saying that the correct way to create change is to tell people that they need to advocate for yourself. That's the only way to change the system.
The hard part about that is when you are in that situation, you feel so helpless that even if you do speak up some doctors still won't listen.
Last year I went to the hospital twice, and have been to almost 7 specialists. In the end I was diagnosed with narcolepsy type 1. As a tiny young woman, 18 at the time, 5'2" and under 100 lbs ( I'm just built small). I had doctors tell me that I'm: a normal college student, depressed, anorexic, just growing, anemic, or being dramatic. I've even had a doctor tell me that I was bed ridden because I was a lesbian!!! Absolutely all of this was not true. I even had family with me to help me explain to them the severity of my symptoms. I don't know how to fix this problem but it's definitely not just a problem of not insisting enough.

snippet.textDisplay: I work in a hospital and I can tell you that...yes. Not everything is perfect and doctors do over look certain complaints and this can be due to bias in medicine. But another aspect which I wished was talked about was physician burnout. Medical professionals are constantly pushed by administration to see as many patients as possible and push them out as quickly as they came in so that the hospital makes more money. If your dr. Is burned out or has been doing a 16 hr shift, they aren’t going to be as in tune with their patients as one would like. Also, if you don’t like your dr. For any reason...FIND A NEW ONE. Many times, a pt will stay w/ the same physician for years even when they have serious complaints. I know it’s hard because you have to find someone in network, and geographically close to you....but you should at least try. The effort you put in to find the right dr. now, could affect your life later.

snippet.textDisplay: This is sad!! I was in a similar situation with my daughter for 2 weeks going back and forth to her pediatrician and the ER. They kept sending us home. Come to find out, the surgery wasn't the right thing for her. Thank God these doctors looked further. At 18 months, my baby was diagnosed with cancer in her pelvic area. Thank God she was able to fight it and win. Thanks to a local St Jude Affiliate. My baby is well and back to growing. Sad part is... I was turned down by so many local lawyers. Not one wanted to help fight after they heard my story. Fyi: most of the local lawyers in my area that deals with malpractice is not of color. Which I don't see color... But looking into it. Made me feel that way. Especially with the first one I thought would have my back and decided not to work with me. The world is changing in a more clear way. I'm just blessed to have my baby girl! snippet.textDisplay:
The American healthcare system is all a sham. it doesn't matter if it's free or not. This doesn't just happen to black people of color. It happens to immigrant people of color, too. I am not black nor white, but I lost a parent not too long ago under the same circumstances as Loni's guilt-ridden friend. My family member was transferred to a recovery center- where she was supposed to recover- but the new medical team took one look at them and for weeks they basically let my loved one wither and die. The nursing staff were lazy and I had to fight to get their attention. Some young medical school interns said the same thing about the poor service.

When something was very wrong, I remained calm, called for help and tried not to panic so they would do their job. I was hoping for the best, but guess what? They just stood by and let my loved one die. That's it. I was in utter disbelief. It was the most traumatic experience I've ever gone through. I've been overcome with guilt and depression ever since.

snippet.textDisplay: I was not aware about this black bias in the medical field, in hospitals & honestly this is so sad. I'm shocked hospitals won't take people seriously just because of their race. Wtf?!? These are people lives on line

snippet.textDisplay: I am so glad I had a black nurse during my labor & delivery. She was sent from the heavens. She took care of me so well I felt like I knew her all my life. Hearing Tam's story made me tear up. Doctors sometimes makes mistakes, but there's a difference in a mistake & just failing to communicate with or respect your patient. Now a days when  I go in to the doctor, I ensure that my doctors SIT DOWN with me. It is also important that we are open & honest with our doctors, no matter how embarrassing. I tell my doctors that I KNOW MY BODY. If they want to run XYZ test, I  want to know the results and it be explained to me to the fullest.
